examples.english: I lost my keys in some bar.

raw_glosses: (transitive) To lose (to cause to cease to be in one's possession or capability due to unfortunate or unknown circumstances/events/reasons)
glosses: To lose (to cause to cease to be in one's possession or capability due to unfortunate or unknown circumstances/events/reasons)

examples.english: I tried to lose him/her in the woods.

raw_glosses: (transitive) To lose, make vanish (to voluntarily make something disappear)
glosses: To lose, make vanish (to voluntarily make something disappear)

examples.ref: 2008, Sami Sillanpää, “Hintojen nousu huolettaa kadunmiestä”, in Helsingin Sanomat
examples.english: Rise in prices a source of worry for the man on the street

examples.text: Kadunmiehen (tai kadulle joutuneen asuntovelallisen) oikeuskatsomuksissa menettely vivahti mielivaltaan.
examples.ref: 2012, Teemu Keskisarja, Markku Kuisma, Erehtymättömät: Tarina suuresta pankkisodasta ja liikepankeista Suomen kohtaloissa 1862-2012
examples.english: The procedure seemed arbitrary to those with the legal understanding of the man on the street (or of whoever had been forced homeless by being unable to pay their mortgage).

examples.text: Kadunmies tietää, että globaalin talouden notkahdukset on kestettävä ja EU:n säätämistä velvoitteista on suoriuduttava.
examples.english: The man on the street knows that one must survive the dips in the global economy and carry out the obligations set out by the EU.

raw_glosses: (idiomatic) man on the street, man in the street, average Joe (an ordinary member of the general public)
glosses: man on the street, man in the street, average Joe (an ordinary member of the general public)

examples.text: {{quote-book|fi|year=2016|author=Tenho N. Suomaa|title=Homo Petroleum|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wqILDAAAQBAJ|isbn=9789523304321|text=Näin kulkureita ja kadunmiehiä sillan alla ja ajattelin että kadunmiehiä haukuttiin turhaan vain 'kadunmiehiksi', vaikka he saivat kävellä rajoituksitta sen päällä!|t=I saw tramps and vagrants under the bridge and thought to myself that vagrants are only called mockingly "kadunmies (vagrant, lit. man of the street)", even though they were allowed to walk on it without any restrictions!}}
Ullanlinnan Arska oli kaupungin kiltein kadunmies, kuvailevat muistopaikalle saapuneet ystävät.
examples.ref: 2017, Karoliina Paananen, “”Helsingin kiltein” kadunmies Arska on poissa – jopa Andy McCoy piipahti kaatamassa oluen muistomerkillä”, in Ilta-Sanomat
examples.english: Ullanlinna Arska was described as the nicest vagrant in town by his friends that had come to visit the memorial site.

examples.text: Kadunmies yritti kaikin tavoin herättää partion huomion.
examples.english: The vagrant tried everything to capture the patrol's attention.

forms.form: Rare. Only used with substantive adjectives.

words.etymology_text: From Proto-Finnic *kadeh (compare Estonian kade, Karelian kajeh, Livonian kaʼd, Veps kadeh, Votic kateh), borrowed from Proto-Germanic *skaþiz (compare Gothic 𐍃𐌺𐌰𐌸𐌹𐍃 (skaþis)).
categories: Requests for tone in Zulu verb entries

words.etymology_text: Borrowed from Russian кади́ло (kadílo), from Old East Slavic кадило (kadilo), from Proto-Slavic *kadidlo, from *kaditi + *-dlo.

categories: Requests for native script for Northern Selkup terms
words.etymology_text: From Proto-Finnic *kadot'ak, from Proto-Uralic *kaďa(w)- (“to leave”). Cognates are found in almost every Uralic language, e.g. Northern Sami guođđit (“to leave something, to depart”), Skolt Sami kue´đđed (“to leave smth”), Moksha кадомс (kadoms, “to leave”), Erzya кадомс (kadoms, “to leave”), Eastern Mari кодаш (kodaš, “to stay”), Udmurt кыльыны (kyľyny, “to stay”), Hungarian hagy (“to let; to leave”), Mansi хули (huli, “to leave”), Northern Selkup [script needed] (kuetja-, “to leave (behind)”) (Taz). Labialization of the stem vowel occurred in Proto-Finnic, compare Estonian kadu (“loss”), Estonian kaduma.
